tossups.question: C. ljungdahlii (“SEE-lung-DOLL-ee-ai”) converts syn·gas into this compound and acetate. Renewable polyethylene is made by harvesting this compound from bagasse (“buh-GASS”), then dehydrating and polymerizing it. Etymologically, the word enzyme derives from proteins like zymase (“ZAI-maze”) that make this chemical anaerobically by de·carboxyl·ating pyruvate, then reducing acetaldehyde (“ASS-uh-TAL-duh-hide”). A 10 percent solution of this liquid is used today instead of (*) tetra·ethyl lead to prevent knocking. This industrial chemical is made by hydrolyzing the cellulose in sugarcane, feeding the glucose to Saccharomyces, and finally distilling this product to its azeotrope. In the US, this biofuel is made from corn and added to gasoline. For 10 points, yeasts ferment sugar into what simple alcohol?
tossups.answer: ethanol [or ethyl alcohol; accept C2H5OH (“C-2-H-5-O-H”) or C2H6O (“C-2-H-5-O-H”); prompt on alcohol]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~27604~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: These people routinely lost claims to land due to the “ten-owner rule.” In 1977, OMAC activists from this group allied with a Trades Council to stop the construction of a housing estate on Bastion Point Reserve. The 2022 biopic Whina (“FEE-nuh”) celebrated an activist of these people who staged a 1975 Land March to assert treaty rights. The Boyd Massacre decreased contact between this group and (*) pākehā. In the 19th century, these people adapted their pā villages to better defend against newly introduced weapons. An 1840 treaty asserting these people would retain “sovereignty” of their lands was signed with William Hobson. For 10 points, the Treaty of Waitangi (“WHY-tahn-gee”) was signed between white settlers and what Indigenous people of New Zealand?
tossups.answer: Māori [prompt on Indigenous New Zealanders or New Zealanders or kiwis until “New Zealand” is read]
tossups.metadata: Benjamin Chapman, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~27112~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: The author of this series started writing it around the time he wrote An Evening with Margaret Mead, inspired by the possibility of art as explored in his autobiographical work How I Learned What I Learned. This series’s characters include a harmonica player called both Canewell and Stool Pigeon and a healer who dies at age 366 called Aunt Ester. Gem of the Ocean and (*) Radio Golf bookend this series, whose ten entries are each set in a different decade of the 20th century. In an entry in this series, a potential football scholarship sparks a disagreement between Cory and Troy Maxson. For 10 points, Fences is in what series of plays by August Wilson, largely set in a Pennsylvania city?
tossups.answer: Pittsburgh Cycle [accept American Century Cycle before “century”; accept the August Wilson Century Cycle before “Wilson”]
tossups.metadata: Joseph Krol, Literature - American - Drama> ~28180~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: In a party convention during this election, a candidate described community organizations as “spread like stars throughout the Nation.” A candidate in this election dropped out after reusing phrases from a Neil Kinnock speech. An ad in this election showing actors walking in and out of a building targeted a candidate who was asked if he would still oppose the death penalty if his (*) wife Kitty was a victim of a violent crime. That candidate in this election was targeted by the “Willie Horton” ad. This election’s winning candidate lost in the next election in part due to his broken promise of “Read my lips: no new taxes.” For 10 points, name this presidential election where Michael Dukakis lost to George H.W. Bush.
tossups.answer: US presidential election of 1988 [prompt on ’88]

tossups.question: In a musical set at one of these places, an evangelist-turned-nightclub-singer performs the number “Blow, Gabriel, Blow.” Nicely-Nicely Johnson invents a dream about being saved from hell in a song titled for one of these places in which “the people all said sit down.” One of these places is the setting of the Cole Porter musical Anything Goes. Another one of these places called the Cotton Blossom titles a pioneering 1927 musical that introduced (*) Paul Robeson’s signature song. The actress Julie sings “Can’t Help Lovin’ Dat Man” in a musical by Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein titled for a “show” type of these places that features the song “Ol’ Man River.” For 10 points, name these vehicles such as the SS American.
tossups.answer: boats [or ships; accept ocean liners or cruise ships; accept river boat or steam boat; accept “Sit Down, You’re Rockin’ the Boat”; accept Show Boat; prompt on at sea or Atlantic Ocean by asking “what kind of place on the ocean?”] (The second line is from Guys and Dolls.)
tossups.metadata: Joseph Krol, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~28096~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: This activity titles a 2018 film where a five-year-old named Yuri with scars on her body is taken in by a poverty-stricken family. That film titled for this activity was directed by Hirokazu Kore-eda. In 2023, the NRF retracted a claim that this activity was primarily done by organized groups. A book whose title encouraged readers to perform this action describes slug coins in its “Survive” section and was written by Yippie co-founder (*) Abbie Hoffman. People engaging in this activity are the primary source of a metric called “shrinkage.” In 2023, an executive at Walgreens admitted his company had over-emphasized how much this crime was contributing to store closures. For 10 points, name this crime made easier by the rise of self-checkout kiosks.
tossups.answer: shoplifting [or stealing; or retail theft; or larceny; or shop theft; accept Shoplifters or Steal This Book; prompt on organized crime or retail fraud]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~28164~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: A state of matter named for this scientist that is derived from a strontium Bose–Einstein condensate can contain 170 strontium atoms within one atom. This scientist’s “polaron” involves a namesake type of atom that has an electron with an extremely large principal quantum number. Subscripts of infinity and “H” distinguish versions of this scientist’s namesake constant for heavy atoms and hydrogen, respectively. Evaluating a formula named for this scientist at “n-sub-one equals one” while varying n-sub-two yields the (*) Lyman series. This scientist’s namesake formula gives the vacuum wavenumber of photons emitted by electronic transitions. For 10 points, name this Swedish physicist who names a constant denoted R.
tossups.answer: Johannes Rydberg [or Johannes Robert Rydberg or Janne Robert Rydberg]
tossups.metadata: Benjamin Chapman, Science - Physics> ~25996~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: This emotion appears second in the name of cultures studied by Julien Pitt-Rivers that display challenge-riposte dialectics. Four maladaptive responses to this emotion are grouped in Nathanson’s “Compass of” this moral emotion, which June Tangney argues arises from evaluations of the global self rather than one’s behavior. The word haji is analyzed in a 1946 study that argues that a culture (*) defined by this emotion acts to avoid ostracism instead of internal moral struggles. This emotion is emphasized in Japan as compared to American guilt culture according to Ruth Benedict’s The Chrysanthemum and the Sword. Revenge and honor killings are believed to prevent, for 10 points, what self-conscious feeling of regret and disgrace?
tossups.answer: shame [accept shaming or being ashamed; accept shame culture; prompt on honor-shame cultures; prompt on embarrassment or word forms like being embarrassed; prompt on humiliation]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Social Science - Anthropology> ~28525~ <Editor: Vincent Du

tossups.question: This figure names a cave system where Snorri Sturlson’s son was castrated and blinded, as related by the Sturlunga Saga. This figure will move from the south with the scourge of branches to arrive first at the field of Vigriðr (“VEE-gree-dor”). This figure will slay Beli’s bane, because the latter had given his sword to Skirnir. This wielder of a (*) “bright sword” will lead a giant army over the Bifrost which will crumble in their wake. Líf and Lífþrasir (“leef-THRA-seer”), the last of humanity, will hide in Hoddmímis holt to escape the devastation wrought by this slayer of Freyr at Ragnarok’s conclusion. For 10 points, name this guardian of Muspelheim, a giant destined to burn the Earth with flame.
tossups.answer: Surtr [or Surt] (The first line refers to the removal of one testicle and the blinding of one eye in Surtshellir.)
tossups.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - World Mythology> ~27504~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: This poet contrasted Grishkin, who distills “a feline smell,” with John Webster, who “saw the skull beneath the skin.” This poet wrote that a new work of art modifies “existing monuments” in an essay advocating for authors to learn literary history. A reference to Shakespeare in the line “The Chair she sat in, like a burnished throne” appears in one of this author’s (*) footnotes. That poem by this author quotes Baudelaire in its description of an “Unreal City under the brown fog of a winter dawn.” This poet repeated the Sanskrit word “shantih” to end the “What the Thunder Said” section of a poem he dedicated to Ezra Pound. For 10 points, name this modernist poet of “The Waste Land.”
tossups.answer: T. S. Eliot (The unnamed works are “Whispers of Immortality” and “Tradition and the Individual Talent.”)
tossups.metadata: Yingzhi Nyang, Literature - British - Poetry> ~27743~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: A 2023 New York Times feature revealed that Senator Mike Lee was on a mailing list of this man’s “extended family” of former employees. Joel Anderson traveled to Pin Point, Georgia to interview this man’s mother, Leola, for Slow Burn. Adam Liptak claimed that a question about “1-800-PLUMBING” was exemplary of how remote COVID-19 policies broke this man’s decade-long “silence.” This man’s wife co-founded Groundswell and received 80 thousand dollars from (*) Leonard Leo of the Federalist Society. Revelations from ProPublica that this RV owner took several vacations funded by billionaire Harlan Crow sparked a statement on ethics by John Roberts. For 10 points, name this conservative Black Supreme Court justice.
tossups.answer: Clarence Thomas

tossups.question: Thomas Fearnley and Charles Cope were among those who painted this short artist standing on benches on “Varnishing Days,” on which he completed paintings just before they were exhibited. The first volume of John Ruskin’s Modern Painters championed this artist over the Old Masters. This artist donated two paintings on the condition that they be hung beside works by Claude Lorrain, who inspired his seascape (*) Dido Building Carthage. Events on the Zong inspired a painting by this artist in which chains and drowning limbs emerge from the sea. In another painting by this artist, a blurry rabbit dashes across a bridge as a train approaches. For 10 points, name this British painter of The Slave Ship and Rain, Steam, and Speed.
tossups.answer: J. M. W. Turner [or Joseph Mallord William Turner]
tossups.metadata: Yingzhi Nyang, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~27308~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: A play by this author ends with a voice calling “he is the God of Love” as a man dies in an avalanche. Another play by this author ends with the Button Molder stating “We meet at the final crossroads” as the protagonist is cradled by Solveig (“sool-VAY”). Another play by this author ends with a man being called “the one cock in the basket” and declaring “people don’t (*) do such things!” One play by this author of Brand ends with a man asking “The most wonderful thing of all?” In a play by this author, George Tesman’s wife shoots herself in the head offstage. A play by this author ends with a door slamming as Nora Helmer leaves her husband. For 10 points, what Norwegian playwright of Peer Gynt wrote Hedda Gabler and A Doll’s House?
tossups.answer: Henrik Ibsen [or Henrik Johan Ibsen]
tossups.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - European - Drama> ~28161~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

tossups.question: The structure of these diagrams is inferred by the MrBayes and MEGA (“mega”) software packages. Coalescent theory interprets these diagrams backwards-in-time to figure out when a random variable diverged. These diagrams are constructed from binary character tables by assigning syn·apo·morphies to an in·group in systematics. Linus Pauling proposed calibrating these diagrams by aligning (*) genes like cyto·chrome C, which are so essential that their sequences mutate like clockwork. On these diagrams, the principle of parsimony dictates that members of a clade which have a homologous structure also probably shared a common ancestor. For 10 points, name these diagrams that illustrate evolutionary history using branches and roots.
tossups.answer: phylogenetic trees [or phylogeny or phylogenies; accept evolutionary trees before “evolutionary” is read; accept cladogram or dendrogram or chronogram; prompt on trees; prompt on tree(s) of life; prompt on networks or Bayesian networks or Bayes nets]
tossups.metadata: David Bass, Science - Biology> ~27417~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: Numerous royal rituals were recorded in this language in the Uigwe (“oo-EEG-way”). A woodblock version of the Tripitaka in this language was printed during invasions by the Khitans. The Gabo Reform, which regulated official documents written in this language, was passed by a king whose death sparked the March 1st Movement. A system for this language was created by a king who destroyed an island base for (*) wokou pirates in the Gihae (“GEE-heh”) Expedition. This language’s “Old” form ended with the fall of the Silla Kingdom. In the 15th century, the Hall of Worthies created a treatise outlining a written script for this language which replaced the Chinese-based hanja. For 10 points, Sejong the Great developed what language’s Hangul alphabet?
tossups.answer: Korean [or Hangugeo] (The second clue refers to the Goryeo Tripitaka.)
tossups.metadata: Lalit Maharjan, History - World - Asian> ~28627~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: In the Serer faith, saltigues (“saul-tee-gways”) step into a circle to publicly engage in this activity in the Xooy (“hoy”) ceremony. Opele chains can be used to perform this activity quickly. During this activity, ivory or wood tappers are tapped on an opon tray to draw the attention of Eshu who acts as a mediator. Babalawos dub palm nuts “open” or “closed” when performing this activity’s “Ifá” form for their clients. Various African diaspora faiths accomplish this activity by tossing (*) cowrie shells and interpreting their landing positions. Roman augurs observed bird omens and examined animal entrails to practice this activity. For 10 points, what activity involved men communing with the gods to predict events to come?
tossups.answer: divination [or predicting the future; or fortune-telling or similar; accept sortition or casting lots; accept molybdomancy or favomancy or astragalomancy; accept haruspicy; accept answers of learning the unknown; accept Ifá prior to mention; prompt on seeking healing or seeking spiritual guidance or communing with the gods by asking “through what means?”]
tossups.metadata: Athena Kern, RMP - Other Religion> ~26158~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: Dynamical friction becomes inefficient at values on the order of this unit, well before the inspiral stage, in this unit’s “final problem.” When d is expressed in this unit, log-base-ten of d equals one plus one-fifth times a “modulus” equal to little m minus big M. This unit is typically used to report the reciprocal of a small angle denoted p or pi. Kilometers per second per (*) million of this unit is the typical compound unit for Hubble’s constant. This unit, which is roughly equal to three light-years, is defined as the distance at which an object has a parallax of one arcsecond. For 10 points, name this astronomical unit of distance that is often misidentified as a unit of time.
tossups.answer: parsecs [or pcs] (The “small angle” is the parallax angle.)
tossups.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, Science - Astronomy> ~28659~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: A passage by this author describes how a writer who “draws the world” finds that he has drawn his own face by the end of his life. A review by this real-life author lauds the choice to purposely give the incorrect solution to a murder mystery by Herbert Quain. This author attacked the heretical viewpoints of Nils Runeberg, including a hypothesis that God was Judas. This author described an attempt to recreate (*) Don Quixote line-by-line by his friend Pierre Menard. This author described an incomplete novel that took the form of a physical labyrinth representing all possible futures. For 10 points, name this author who used fictional criticism in works like “The Garden of Forking Paths.”
tossups.answer: Jorge Luis Borges [or Jorge Francisco Isidoro Luis Borges Acevedo]
tossups.metadata: Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~28416~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: Soldiers argued that this person was cryptically mentioned in a set of erotic correspondences written to the Italian attaché Alessandro Panizzardi. While being arrested, Charles Maurras (“more-OSS”) supposedly shouted that this person got revenge; Maurras founded Action Française (“frahn-SEZ”) during an event involving this person. The newspaper La Libre Parole frequently attacked this person based on documents that included a (*) “bordereau” discovered in a wastebasket. Georges Picquart (“pee-KAR”) investigated actions supposedly committed by this person after he was sent to Devil’s Island in 1895 for the crimes of Ferdinand Esterhazy. For 10 points, Emile Zola penned “J’accuse” in defense of what Jewish military officer who was accused of treason?
tossups.answer: Alfred Dreyfus
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - European - 1500-1900> ~27128~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: This instrument plays a languid melody representing a lazy layabout in the Preludio of Heitor Villa-Lobos’s (“VEE-yah LOH-bohsh’s”) second Bachiana Brasileira (“bah-kee-AH-nuh brah-see-LAY-ruh”). Sigurd Raschèr’s virtuosity on this instrument inspired Jacques Ibert’s (“ee-BAIR”) Concertino da Camera. A solo for this instrument begins “Waltz No. 2” from Shostakovich’s first Suite for Variety Orchestra. After a G-sharp minor bassoon solo in 6/8 (“six eight”) time, this instrument plays the melody in (*) Maurice Ravel’s orchestration of “The Old Castle” from Pictures at an Exhibition. Created by a Belgian inventor in the mid-1800s, this instrument comes in a tenor version in B-flat and a more common E-flat alto version. For 10 points, name this woodwind instrument made of brass.
tossups.answer: saxophone [accept tenor saxophone; accept alto saxophone]
tossups.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~27615~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: Almost verbless poems in this language like “Storm in the sky in the evening” inspired this language’s Imaginism movement. A poet compared himself to Anne Frank in a poem in this language about the site of an atrocity where “no monument stands.” A thick-fingered man who “forges decrees” and “rolls executions on his tongue” was described in an “Epigram” in this language by an (*) Acmeist (“ACK-me-ist”) poet. The section “Instead of a Preface” opens a poem in this language about the imprisonment of its author’s son, “Requiem.” This language of “Babi Yar” is used in a poem whose title character duels Lensky and rejects Tatiana. For 10 points, name this language used by Anna Akhmatova (“akh-MAT-oh-vah”) and the author of Eugene Onegin (“ohn-YAY-gin”), Alexander Pushkin.
tossups.answer: Russian [or Russkiy] (The power clues are Afanasy Fet, Yevgeny Yevtushenko’s “Babi Yar”, and Osip Mandelstam’s “Stalin Epigram.”)
tossups.metadata: Yingzhi Nyang, Literature - European - Poetry> ~25348~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

bonuses.leadin: This author was dubbed “the conscience of the nation” as part of Germany’s “rubble literature” movement. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author. Robert Faehmel destroys St. Anthony’s Abbey to punish those who collaborated with “the Host of the Beast” in this author’s 1959 novel Billiards at Half-Past Nine.
This author’s Nobel Prize citation praises his 1959 book The Tin Drum for reviving German literature from “linguistic and moral destruction.”

This author of Vertigo said he hated the German postwar novel “like pestilence.” This author included photographs in a novel in which Jacques researches his mother’s internment in a concentration camp, Austerlitz.
answers: W. G. Sebald [or Winfried Georg Sebald; or Max Sebald]
bonuses.metadata: Yingzhi Nyang, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~22891~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

bonuses.leadin: Art historians often classify art from Calakmul as part of a “style” named for these objects. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these objects, only four of which from one culture survive today. One of these objects in Dresden cannot be rearranged into the proper order because the Amatl has adhered to a glass display.
Calakmul was a site of this Mesoamerican culture. Artists from this culture include Lakam Chahk, whose name derives from these people’s axe-wielding god of rain, Chahk.

One example of the Codex Style is a vessel from Calakmul of a maize god in this pose. Henry Moore was inspired by Chac Mool figures to create sculptures of people in this title pose, including one outside the UNESCO headquarters.
answers: codices [accept Codex Style; accept, but DO NOT REVEAL, Mayan codices; prompt on manuscripts; reject “books”]
Mayan people [or Mayan culture; accept K’iche Maya or Yucatec Maya or Qʼeqchi Maya or Mopan Maya or Ixil Maya]
reclining [accept Reclining Figure; accept reclining nudes; accept laying down; prompt on resting or leaning; prompt on sleeping or dying by asking “what physical action is the figure doing?”]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Painting - World> ~22850~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: A 2024 study found Alzheimer’s disease can be transmitted via contaminated stocks of this protein extracted from human cadavers. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this pituitary hormone that is now made synthetically for patients with short stature.

Fears of contagious Alzheimer’s echo the early 2000s paranoia surrounding this disease. For two decades, the FDA banned blood donations from European travelers, fearing this disease could seed a Creutzfeldt-Jakob epidemic.
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is also spread by surgeons using contaminated scalpels to graft this outer layer of the meninges. This tough tissue surrounds the brain’s arachnoid layer.
answers: human growth hormone [or growth hormone; or GH or hGH; or somatotropin]
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~23261~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: Occasionalism is the view that all events are caused by this figure. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this figure. Al-Ghazali tried using logic to show that this figure, rather than natural laws, is the reason that cotton catches on fire.

Al-Ghazali’s faith-based philosophy was criticized by this other Islamic thinker, who supported the Aristotelian theory of causality. This philosopher was known as “the Commentator” and wrote The Incoherence of the Incoherence.
Two answers required. In his initial formulation of causality, Aristotle outlined four types of causes that beget the different natures of a material. Name any two of them.
answers: material OR formal OR efficient OR final causes [accept hule OR eidos OR kinoun OR telos; accept teleological in place of “final”]
bonuses.metadata: Ethan Ashbrook, RMP - Philosophy> ~22936~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: In a short story by this author, a couple is too busy bickering to notice that their cab driver ran over a human child instead of a goat. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of the collection The Assassination of Margaret Thatcher. This author depicted the rise of Thomas Cromwell in her novel Wolf Hall.

The narrator of Mantel’s story “Destroyed” imagines this “beautiful word” in her mind while looking for a dog. This word titles a story in which a trapped man makes an “idiotic” laugh after seeing wolves running down a hill.
Mantel praised this author of the short story “Widows” as a “realist with wings.” This author also wrote The Handmaid’s Tale.
answers: Hilary Mantel [or Dame Hilary Mary Mantel; accept Hilary Mary Thompson] (The story from the lead-in is “Winter Break.”)
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - British - Short Fiction> ~23805~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: A phrase used by this group became synonymous with conjunctivitis since an outbreak coincided with a mass emigration of this ethnicity. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ethnolinguistic group. Sheikh Hasina’s father, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, founded the Awami League to agitate for the creation of an independent nation for this ethnic group.
This Indian prime minister supported the rebels during the Bangladeshi Liberation War. This daughter of Jawaharlal Nehru was assassinated by her Sikh bodyguards in 1984.
The Bengali genocide began with this 1971 operation, in which hundreds of thousands of Bengali intellectuals were killed by Pakistani soldiers.
answers: Bengalis [prompt on Bangladeshis] (The first clue refers to how conjunctivitis is called “Joi Bangla” in India.)
bonuses.metadata: Hari Parameswaran, History - World - Asian> ~22196~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: This designer claimed to spend most of her free time at the age of six playing with dolls in a graveyard. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this designer who said that Christian Dior “dressed women like armchairs.” This French designer popularized masculine women’s clothing like tweed suits, often in black and white.
With Ernest Beaux, Chanel produced a type of this substance called “No. 5.” These substances have head, heart, and base notes.

A young Chanel did not understand what a tiara was when her lover gave her one produced by this jewelry brand. Aldo Cipullo (“sih-POOL-oh”) designed the difficult-to-remove Love Bracelet for this brand.
answers: perfumes [or scents; or fragrances; accept eau de parfum or eau de toilette or eau de cologne; prompt on aromas or odors]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~22150~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: The urdhva pundra is one of these markings that resembles Vishnu’s foot. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these Hindu markings created from a blend of sandalwood paste and dyes. A sacred ash known as vibhuti is used to create these markings in the form of three lines, creating a tripundra.

Tilaka are placed over the ajna instance of these things which represents the third eye. These things, which derive from the Sanskrit word for “wheel,” are located at the spinal junctures of the nadis.
Worshippers of Devi and Shiva place a red dot in the middle of the tilak as it is drawn on this area of the body. Another red dot known as the bindi is placed on this area by married women.
answers: forehead [accept between the eyes or between the eyebrows; prompt on head or face]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, RMP - Hinduism> ~23693~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: Clearchus of Soli hinted that this woman inspired Diotima, an “accomplished sophist” who appears in Plato’s Symposium. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this courtesan and lover of Pericles who hosted symposiums and dispensed relationship advice from her Athens home.
Aspasia hailed from this city which led the Ionian Revolt. Anaximander studied a philosopher who made his fortune by using astronomy to predict profitable olive harvests named Thales.

Aspasia’s sister married Alcibiades’s grandfather after he had undergone this procedure in which votes cast via broken pottery shards expelled an Athenian citizen. It names a form of  social banishment.
answers: ostracism [accept word forms such as being ostracized; accept ostrakismos]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - European - Classical> ~22953~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: These objects can be roughly, though circularly, defined as anything that transforms like these objects. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these mathematical objects exemplified in physics by “metric” and “stress–energy” ones.
A distinguishing feature of tensors is that they are multiplied by the Jacobian under this type of operation. Galileo names instances of this type of operation that do not preserve delta-s-squared.

The metric tensor is related to the stress–energy tensor by equations fundamental to this theory. Einstein developed this theory to explain gravitation, extending an earlier theory that uses Lorentz transformations.
answers: tensors [accept metric tensor; accept stress–energy tensor; prompt on matrix or matrices]

coordinate transformations [accept descriptions of changing coordinate systems or changing reference frame or change of basis; prompt on transformations or Galilean transformations by asking “of what?”; prompt on descriptions of change of variables by asking “which variables?”]
general relativity [or GR or general theory of relativity; prompt on relativity]
bonuses.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~23333~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: The spirit Anoa warns of “predators” and “destroyers” who bring slavery for two thousand of these time periods in an Ayi Kwei Armah novel. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these time periods. The story of Mustafa Sa’eed torments the unnamed narrator of a Tayeb Salih novel titled for one of these time periods “of Migration to the North.”
Anti-colonial themes appear 2016 novel by Yaa Gyasi about how Esi and her descendants grow up in America away from her half-sister Effia’s family in Ghana due to slavery.
Pre-colonial Umuofia is described as “the terror of their neighbors, before the white men came” in No Longer at Ease, the sequel to this author’s novel Things Fall Apart.
answers: seasons [accept mawsim or mawasim; accept Two Thousand Seasons or Season of Migration to the North or Mawsim al-Hijrah ilâ al-Shamâl]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~23715~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: MicroPADs are microfluidic devices made out of this material. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this cheap material derived from pulped cellulose.
In point-of-care mass spectrometry, liquids wick through a paper micro-PAD, then are released by a spray that performs this process on the analyte. This process also converts gases to plasmas.

Paper is used to concentrate the analyte in wearable biosensors that rely on the surface-enhanced form of this analytical assay. This technique measures the weak vibrational transitions that resonate with the energy difference between incident and emitted scattered light.
answers: ionization [or ionizing; or forming ions; prompt on charging or loss of electrons]
Raman spectroscopy [or Raman scattering; or surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy or SERS]
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~22769~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: Branscombe and Wann found that this concept was reduced in American students when they were shown clips of Rocky IV (“4”) edited so that Ivan Drago won the match. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this concept measured by the Rosenberg scale. This concept, which some propose acts as a “sociometer,” is negatively affected by upward comparison.
People who believe they have this quality tend to have higher self-esteem. In most cultures, facial symmetry is linked with this quality.

Terror management theory holds that anxiety about this concept compels people to adopt worldviews that protect their self-esteem. A Freudian “drive” named for this concept leads people towards self-destructive acts.
answers: self-esteem [or self-worth; or self-respect; prompt on self-concept or self-evaluation; prompt on self-belief or self-confidence]
physical attractiveness [or beauty; accept reasonable synonyms like being good-looking, pretty, handsome or sexy]
death [accept word forms like dying; accept the death drive; prompt on Thanatos]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Social Science - Psychology> ~22187~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Yale Series of Younger Poets, which publishes a debut collection each year, for 10 points each.
parts: The series is considered to have peaked while this author of “September 1, 1939” and “Funeral Blues” served as judge.
The 1950 prize was awarded by Auden to this poet for her collection A Change of World. The final stanza of a poem by this author describes “carrying…a book of myths in which our names do not appear.”

Auden also awarded the prize to an author with this surname who wrote a poem titled for “Lying in a Hammock” at a farm. In a novel by an author with this surname, the protagonist kills a rat with a skillet and later accidentally suffocates a Communist girl.
answers: Adrienne Rich (The unnamed poem is “Diving into the Wreck.”)
Wright [or Richard Wright; or Richard Nathanael Wright; or James Wright; or James Arlington Wright] (The novel in the second sentence is Native Son.)
bonuses.metadata: Chandler West, Literature - American - Poetry> ~23316~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about education in antebellum America, for 10 points each.
parts: This law required that each newly created township have land specially allocated for schools. Its other provisions included outlining the process for which territories became states.
A kindergarten advocate from this family wrote the advice manual The American Woman’s Home. Another member of this family wrote Uncle Tom’s Cabin.
Horace Mann was inspired by an approach to science education named for this family. A member of this family who wrote Cosmos described guano and the properties of cinchona bark from his travels.
answers: Northwest Ordinance [or the Northwest Ordinance of 1787; accept the Ordinance of 1787 or An Ordinance for the Government of the Territory of the United States, North-West of the River Ohio]
Beecher [accept Catharine Beecher or Harriet Beecher Stowe; prompt on Stowe]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - American - Pre-1865> ~22427~ <Editor: Arjun Nageswaran

bonuses.leadin: This adjective titles a “Symphony” for soprano and baritone soloists inspired by Rabindranath Tagore’s The Gardener. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this adjective that titles Alexander von Zemlinsky’s most famous work. Alban Berg quoted that work in a six-movement “suite” for string quartet titled for this adjective.
Berg used this compositional technique in the Lyric Suite. Zemlinsky’s student Arnold Schoenberg developed this serialist, atonal technique that uses all notes of the chromatic scale.
This composer included “Wedding Day at Troldhaugen” in his collection Lyric Pieces. He also wrote “In the Hall of the Mountain King” for the play Peer Gynt.
answers: lyric [accept Lyric Symphony or Lyrische Symphonie; accept Lyric Suite or Lyrische Suite]
twelve-tone technique [or twelve-tone serialism or twelve-note composition or dodecaphony or Zwölftontechnik]
bonuses.metadata: Ivvone Zhou, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~23113~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

bonuses.leadin: WIthin months of landing, members of this group had managed to consume all of their nearby cabbage palms “within a dozen miles.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this alliteratively named group of convicts and colonists that arrived in Botany Bay in 1788.
The First Fleet abandoned Botany Bay for this city, which they named after a Home Secretary. A food crisis was alleviated by the Third Fleet’s arrival in this capital of New South Wales.

150 years before the First Fleet, a ship of this name wrecked off Western Australia. This is also the name of the capital of the Dutch East Indies and a Republic established in The Netherlands in 1795.
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~20861~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: In the 1990s, the popularity of a fried spider dish made from tarantulas called a-ping took off in this country. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country whose currency, the riel, legendarily is named for a type of fish. This Asian country shares the Dangrek Mountains with its [emphasize] western neighbor.
This largest freshwater body in Cambodia is the source of the trey riel fish that is often used to make prahok. In the dry season, this body of water is drained southeastward to the Mekong River.

Somewhere between June and November, the Tonlé Sap reverses direction as a result of heavy rains brought by this seasonal weather pattern. South Asia gets heavy rains during the “bursts” of these events.
answers: Tonlé Sap Lake [or Tonle Sap River; or Tônlé Sab; or Biển Hồ; prompt on Great Lake or Grand Lac]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~23038~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: In 2021, this company began requiring the use of a PAT or S·S·H key instead of a password to authenticate certain user requests. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this company, a competitor of Bitbucket, that provides the largest online version control platform.

Organizations can control access to their GitHub repositories by requiring S·S·O with a SAML (“SAM-ul”), or “security assertion [this type of language],” identity. GitHub READ·ME files are in this type of language exemplified by XML and YAML (“YAM-ul”).
The SAML format borrows XML’s specifications for signing and this property. The RSA algorithm gives data this property, which exists “end-to-end” for many messaging apps.
answers: markup languages [accept lightweight markup languages; prompt on Markdown or md by asking “what type of language is Markdown?”]
encrypted [accept word forms, like encryption; accept XML encryption or RSA encryption; or end-to-end encryption]
bonuses.metadata: David Bass, Science - Computer Science> ~23887~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: This figure proclaims “No one is truly free except for Zeus” while ridiculing a fellow god’s reluctance to bind Prometheus in an Aeschylean tragedy’s opening scene. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this personification of strength and child of the Styx who enforces Zeus’s will alongside his siblings Bia, Zelus, and Nike.
In Prometheus Bound, Kratos reinforces the idea that the titan is being punished for stealing this “special gift” and giving it to man.

Kratos’s hair survives on a battered vase fragment depicting the construction of the fiery wheel meant to torment this king, who had sex with a cloud shaped like Hera and fathered the progenitor of the Centaurs.
bonuses.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~23531~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Medieval European market towns, places with legal charters to allow vendors set up stalls and hawk their goods, for 10 points each.
parts: Many market towns developed due to their proximity to these buildings, which were designed with moats to protect against invaders.
In England, market towns were also periodically host to these local law courts. “Hanging” George Jeffreys presided over “Bloody” versions of these trials in 1685.
The largest inn in a market town was often run by a person who also controlled this service. For two decades, Alexandrine von Taxis controlled this service in the Holy Roman Empire.
answers: postal service [or mail; accept descriptions of delivering letters or packages; accept courier service]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - European - 1500-1900> ~22863~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran
